moves.1... c6 2. Nf3 d5 3. e5: White pushs with intent of staking more space in the center, baring in mind the risk of over-extension.
moves.7... c5: black naturally aims to undermine it.
moves.8. Be2 cxd4 9. Qxd4: white offers to exchange queens early in hopes of leaving  the middle game to whomever is superior in thier minor piece placement .
moves.10. h3 Bf5 11. a4: attempting to claim more space on the queenside relegating castling to lower priority.
moves.11... a6 12. b4 Bc2: white didn't expect a double attack on a4, but it proved escapable anyways.
moves.13. b5 Qe6 14. Qd2 Be4 15. Nd4 Qd7 16. f: Finally castling as a rook move, inorder to double up the rooks on the queenside.
moves.19... Qc5 20. Kh1: relieving the knight pin immediately. (though in hindshight, 20. Be3 may have been worth hanging the e5 pawn in exchange for the tempo & initiative.)
moves.20... Nd7 21. Be3: Not caring too much for the e5 pawn compared to protecting the queenside advantage and the chance to attack the queen.
moves.21... Bxe5 22. Nxe6: ! and this where white expected a great combination of possible attacks, with something along the lines of 22. ... Bxc3 23. Bxc5 Bxd2 24. Nc7  Kd8 25. Nxa8 Nxc5 26. Rf-d1 Bf4 27. Rxd5  Nd7 28. Rb4 Ng-f6 29. Rxd7  Nxd7 30. Rxf4 Ke7 31. Nc7 Nxb6 32. a5 and white would come out ahead.
moves.22... Qe7: But trading queens was once again declined.
moves.23. Nc7+ Bxc7 24. bxc7 b6 25. Rfe1: preparing to pin the queen from atleast 2 moves away.
moves.25... Rc8 26. Bxa6 Qd6: Black sees it, but can't stop it with movement of the queen alone. 26... Ne5 would have fared better.
moves.27. Bc5+: Discovered check and the queen the falls! Black resigns.
